title: What is the story behind the song 'Hotel California' by the Eagles? - Quora

response.answer_text: Glenn Frey has said that the album was the very top of the peak for the Eagles but also marked the beginning of the band’s end. There was nowhere left for the group to go as a unit after such a huge success. Released in 1976 the group’s fifth album sold 16 million copies in the United States and more than 30 million worldwide. Interestingly, Frey and Don Henley and the other Eagles have given different answers to what the title track was about. Depending on who you believe, the song was about a freaky, haunted hotel or the jaw dropping excesses and wild lifestyle of the band in its earlier years. It could be it’s about both. Frey once conceded that not even he or the others really know. Oddly enough, Frey told a BBC interviewer that the original working title of the song was, “Mexican Reggae.” As for the age-old question about whether the Hotel California was or is a real place. Some have said it’s in Todos Santos, in Baja, California. Henley has said it doesn’t exist. It’s not a real place. It’s fun to speculate. But in the end, all that really matters is the music itself—an album that is a pure work of art and one of the greatest rock ’n roll creations ever. Now, please bring me my wine. Additional research sources: How Hotel California destroyed The Eagles Where is Hotel California and is it even a real place.

About a year ago, I listened to an interview with Don Henley from the Eagles who wrote the song while in Southern California. I remember him mentioning being in Malibu at the time. It is about the excesses of a place, the California lifestyle, of being famous and living there (Hotel California) and all that goes along with that. Fame, money, luxury (Mercedes Benz and Tiffany twisted), partying, etc. He mentioned how the band members were not from the West coast (Don Henley from a small Texas town, Glenn Frey from Michigan, etc) and when you move out to (Hotel) California from a much simpler upbringing and in to that excess, you can really “never leave” it behind. It changes you for good. He said “Steely knives“ was a nod to the band Steely Dan. They were getting them back for something they did.  The sound as he described was a “Mexican Reggae”, Rock and Roll. There is a Hotel California in Baja, California but it appears that it has no connection and a coincidence.
